questions.prompt: In BG 2.2, what does Krsna point out to Arjuna?
choices: His military strategy is weak
He is showing weakness and sadness even though he is a warrior
His weapons are not strong enough
He should have run away earlier
questions.feedback: Krsna tells Arjuna that he is acting weakly and unmanly despite being a warrior, and should overcome this weakness.

questions.prompt: In BG 2.3, how does Krsna tell Arjuna to overcome weakness?
choices: By hiding from the battle
By becoming angry
By giving up his sadness and standing up to face his duty
By running away quickly
questions.feedback: Krsna urges Arjuna to stop being sad, stand up, and face what he needs to do with courage.

questions.prompt: What does Arjuna do in BG 2.7?
choices: He insults Krsna
He ignores Krsna's words
He asks Krsna to teach him what he should do
He walks away from the chariot
questions.feedback: Arjuna accepts that he is confused and asks Krsna to teach him the right way to act in this situation.

questions.prompt: In BG 2.11, what does Krsna say wise people understand about mourning?
choices: They mourn only for dead people
They mourn both living and dead equally
They do not mourn excessively for anyone who dies
They mourn for everyone
questions.feedback: Krsna says that wise people understand that mourning endlessly is not the answer, whether for the living or for those who pass away.

questions.prompt: According to BG 2.12, what is true about the soul and individual beings?
choices: They are created only at birth
They exist forever; there was never a time when they did not exist
They are destroyed when the body dies
They are all the same being
questions.feedback: Krsna teaches that individual souls exist eternally; there is no time when they did not exist and no time when they will cease to exist.

questions.prompt: In BG 2.13, what does Krsna compare to the changes in a person's body over time?
choices: Seasons changing
A tree growing
The stages of life from childhood to old age while the person remains the same
A river flowing
questions.feedback: Just as a person grows from childhood to youth to old age but remains the same person, the soul remains eternal while the body changes.

questions.prompt: What does BG 2.14 teach about happiness and sadness?
choices: They are permanent and never change
Happiness is good but sadness is bad forever
They come and go like summer and winter, and we should accept both
We should only feel happiness
questions.feedback: Krsna teaches that happiness and sadness are temporary experiences, like seasons, and the wise person learns to deal with both.

questions.prompt: In BG 2.15, who is ready to reach a higher state of being?
choices: Someone who is disturbed by happiness and sadness
Someone who stays calm and not disturbed by happiness or sadness
Someone who chases happiness
Someone who avoids all responsibility
questions.feedback: A person who remains calm and steady even when experiencing happiness or sadness is qualified to reach a higher spiritual state.

questions.prompt: According to BG 2.17, what is the soul compared to?
choices: The body and senses
Water and air
That which exists throughout the body, cannot be destroyed, and is eternal
A temporary spark
questions.feedback: Krsna describes the soul as eternal and indestructible, present throughout the body, and impossible to harm or destroy.

questions.prompt: In BG 2.20, what is stated about the soul and birth and death?
choices: The soul is born and dies like the body
The soul is born but does not die
The soul has never been born and will never die
Death is the end of everything
questions.feedback: Krsna teaches that the soul does not have birth or death; it is eternal and is not destroyed even when the body dies.

questions.prompt: In BG 2.22, what does Krsna compare to changing clothes?
choices: Life itself
The soul's transition from one body to another
Age and growing up
War and peace
questions.feedback: Krsna uses the simple analogy that just as we change old clothes for new ones, the soul takes on a new body when the old one dies.

questions.prompt: What does BG 2.31 teach about a warrior's duty?
choices: A warrior should never fight
A warrior should only fight for wealth
Fighting for what is right is a warrior's sacred duty
A warrior should become a priest instead
questions.feedback: Krsna teaches that a warrior's duty is to fight righteously, and there is no better engagement for a warrior than to fight for what is right.

questions.prompt: According to BG 2.37, what happens if Arjuna refuses to fight?
choices: He will be hailed as a great pacifist
He will gain immediate peace and happiness
He will lose respect and fail in his duty
He will become wealthier
questions.feedback: Krsna warns that if Arjuna does not do his duty as a warrior, he will be seen as a coward and will lose respect.

questions.prompt: In BG 2.47, what is the main point about doing your duty?
choices: You should do your duty only if you are sure you will win
You should do your duty without being attached to whether you succeed or fail
You should do your duty only if it brings rewards
You should never do your duty
questions.feedback: Krsna teaches that you should do what is right and your duty without worrying too much about whether you win or lose.

questions.prompt: What is Krsna's main message to Arjuna in Chapter 2?
choices: Avoid all conflict and hide
The soul is eternal, so you should do your duty as a warrior without fear
Only material things matter
Grief and sadness are good
questions.feedback: Krsna's main teaching is that since the soul is eternal and cannot be harmed, Arjuna should do his duty as a warrior without being afraid or overwhelmed by sadness.
